awd_titl_txt: Heterogeneity, Household Behavior, and the Transmission of Aggregate Shocks
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

PI Last Name: Auclert
Title: Heterogeneity, Household Behavior, and the Transmission of Aggregate Shocks
Proposal ID:  1851717 


Most of the models used to study monetary and fiscal policy abstract away from inequality and assume that households are rational and perfectly informed about the state of the economy. Considering households that are heterogenous with respect to their consumption, income, wealth, and information sets imposes challenges in modeling. This research develops a codebase in modelling heterogenous decision makers using recent advances in theory and computation. The developed toolkit will include codes, extensive documentation in the form of notebooks, as well as teaching materials. The developed codebase will provide researchers and policy makers a useful toolkit in considering heterogenous households by simplifying the computation and estimation of complex macroeconomic models.  
 
This research on heterogenous agent models leverages new advances on the computation of equilibria in sequence space by jointly solving the equations characterizing equilibrium across all periods for time paths of the unknowns, given initial conditions on the distribution and other states. For models that are linearized to first order with respect to aggregates, the sequence and the state space approaches deliver the same impulse responses, but the sequence space has computational advantages for heterogeneous-agent models: it allows for a wider class of shocks, is easily scalable, and can achieve large speed gains. The developed toolkit will require as input the equations characterizing equilibrium, including specification of heterogeneous-agent ?blocks?. The toolkit will then automatically perform computation of steady state and transition dynamics for given shocks. Extensions will allow estimation as well as computation of optimal policy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project yielded several publications and working papers that develop macroeconomic models with heterogeneous agents, as well as a codebase for solving these types of models that is experiencing fast growth in usage in academia and in policy institutions. We also released public teaching material that summarize the main results and methods from this project. This material was developed as part of a series of workshops for graduate students and central bankers at the NBER and at Goethe University.  

Auclert, Bardoczy, Rognlie and Straub (Econometrica, 2021) lay the foundations for solving general equilibrium heterogeneous-agent models using first-order linearization in the sequence space. The paper provides a method to rapidly obtain the sequence-space Jacobians of any model (the derivatives of its perfect foresight mappings between aggregate sequences around the steady-state), and then applies this method to solve and estimate several models of heterogeneous households, with and without nominal rigidities, and with and without a choice to invest in an illiquid account.  

Auclert, Rognlie and Straub (Journal of Political Economy, forthcoming) provide a general equilibrium model of the dynamic effects of fiscal policy that is consistent with the microeconomic response of consumption to fiscal transfers. The paper identifies intertemporal marginal propensities to consume (iMPCs) as the key sufficient statistic connecting the microeconomic data with the macroeconomic effects of fiscal policy. Models that match empirical iMPCs imply much larger effects of deficit-financed fiscal policy than models that do not. Practically, iMPCs are sequence-space Jacobians of the model, so the paper shows how to use this concept not just as a solution method, but as a way to connect micro data with macroeconomic outcomes.

Auclert, Rognlie and Straub (NBER Working Paper, 2020) propose a model of the monetary transmission mechanism that is not only consistent with micro-level iMPCs, but also with the empirical impulse response of aggregate variables to monetary policy shocks, which is known to feature a "hump" shape. The idea to reconcile these two facts is to introduce sluggishness in the adjustment of households' expectations of aggregate variables, and the paper provides a method for adjusting sequence-space Jacobians to implement this idea in practice. The estimated model implies a large role for investment in the transmission mechanism of monetary policy.

Auclert, Souchier, Rognlie and Straub (NBER Working Paper, 2021) provide an application of the heterogeneous-agent New Keynesian framework developed in these earlier papers to determining the effect of exchange rate changes and monetary policy in a small-open-economy setting. Aggarwal, Auclert, Rognlie and Straub (NBER Macroeconomics Annual, 2022) provide another application, to fiscal policy in a set of large open economies. Auclert, Monnery, Rognlie and Straub (Proceedings of the Annual Conference of the Central Bank of Chile, 2024) provide yet another application, to the effects of energy price shocks in energy-importing economies.  

Auclert, Rigato, Rognlie and Straub (Quarterly Journal of Economics, 2024) show how sequence-space Jacobian methods can be used to shed new light on models with heterogeneous firms that set prices at different times. The paper revisits the aggregate implications of models that match empirical evidence on price-setting for the aggregate Phillips curve--the aggregate relation between marginal costs and inflation.

Further applications of the sequence-space Jacobian methodology solve for the steady state of Ramsey optimal policy plans (in Auclert, Cai, Rognlie and Straub, Working Paper, 2024) as well as for the portfolios of heterogeneous agents in the presence of aggregate risk (in Auclert, Rognlie, Straub and Tapak, 2024). Both problems are extremely challenging to tackle with existing methods in the literature, and the papers illustrate the promise of an approach via sequence-space Jacobians.

We believe that the methods developed as part of this project could become the leading way of solving a large class of macroeconomic models with heterogeneous agents. They would be taught in graduate programs everywhere and used by graduate students and researchers alike when solving their models. This is important because heterogeneity has received increasing attention in macroeconomics, as illustrated by the recent coronavirus recession, which involved complex interactions between household balance sheets and sectoral network effects.
